choices.text: Topical antibiotics should be treatment of choice

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding orbital complication of sinusitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ethmoidal sinusitis is most common
Sol:-

Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital complications due to the thin lamina papyracea separating the ethmoid sinus from the orbit.

Topical antibiotics are not sufficient in orbital complications; systemic antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage are required.

Both anterior and posterior walls can be involved depending on the extent.

Restricted ocular movements and proptosis are common in orbital cellulitis or abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following structure of nasal septum is pointed out?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rostrum of sphenoid
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
MAJOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO SEPTUM:
1. septal cartilage
2. vomer
3. perpendicular plate of ethmoid
MINOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO SEPTUM:
1. nasal spine of frontal bone
2. maxillary spine
3. rostrum of sphenoid
4. crests of maxillary & palatine bones

choices.text: HRCT skull base is the radiological investigation of choice to detect site of leak
Infection is the commonest cause now a days
Immediate transnasal endoscopic surgical closure of leak site should be done
Double ring sign is seen in all cases

questions.text: A patient is referred with history recurrent meningitis.He had a nasal polypectomy 3 years before and since then have been experiencing unilateral nasal discharge.The following is a coronal computed tomography (CT) scan of the sinuses taken on admission.Which of the following is most appropriate statement.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

HRCT skull base is the radiological investigation of choice to detect site of leak
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
• TAU protein (Beta-2 transferrin) on any nasal fluid collected by the patient. The presence of TAU protein is diagnostic of CSF (a serum test for TAU protein if performed helps to increase certainty). There is no modern day role for glucose testing in the investigation of CSF leaks.
• Imaging. High-resolution CT imaging of the skull base is good at identifying the location of leak; however, artefacts can occur (e.g. vessels passing through skull base). The CT is also necessary if navigation-guided surgery is planned. 
• MRI can also be useful in identifying the site if there is also a skull base defect such as meningocele.

questions.text: A patient complaing of chronic nasal obstruction since last 6 months was operated 2 months back and now present with crusts and bleeding.Study the nasal examination image and comment on the surgery which was done ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

SMR.
Ref:Read the text below
Sol

questions.text: A patient presents with greenish black discharge with wide roomy nasal cavity and formation of crusts causing nasal obstruction.on examination patient was having foul smelling crusts i.e merciful anosmia. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atrophic rhinitis 
Sol:
Atrophic rhinitis (OZAENA):
• Progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and the underlying bone of the turbinate and the presence of viscid secretions which from foul smelling crusts and roomy cavities.
• Klebsiella ozaenae (Perez bacillus), Diphtheriods and Bacillus mucosus.
• Usually starts in females.
• Around puberty.
Treatment:
Medical:
• Alkaline douching
(Alkaline solution: - 280 ml warm water + a teaspoonful of the following powder: * Sodium bicarbonate (28.4g)
+ Sodium biborate (28.4g) + Sodium chloride (56.7g).
• Glucose in glycerine.
• Kemicetine antiozaena solution.
• Chloramphenicol.
• Estradiol dipropionate.
• Vitamin D2.
• Human placental extract: tissue therapy with systemic human placenta extract
Surgical Treatment:
Young’s operation:
• Closure of the nostril following elevation of the nasal vestibular folds.
Modified Young’s operation:
• Partial closure of the nostril leaving behind a 3mm hole.
• This remains for a period of 2 years.
Lautenslager’s operation:
• Surgical procedures aimed at medializing the lateral nasal wall.

choices.text: Nasal septum, cephalic margin of the upper lateral cartilages, and the nasal floor
Nasal septum, caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilages, head of the inferior turbinate, and nasal floor
Nasal septum, mid-portion of the upper lateral cartilages, head of the inferior turbinate, nasal floor, and pyriform aperture
Nasal floor, head of the inferior turbinate, and head of the middle turbinate

questions.text: The internal nasal valve is best defined by which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nasal septum, caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilages, head of the inferior turbinate, and nasal floor
Ref:Read the text below
Sol
The internal nasal valve is comprised of 
(1) Nasal septum,
(2) Caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage
(3) Head of the inferior turbinate
(4) Nasal floor.

choices.text: The inspiratory and expiratory air currents pass through middle part of nasal cavity
Sinuses are mainly ventilated during inspiratory phase of respiration
Nasal cilia beat 10-20 times per second and mucociliary clearance time is 10 -20 minutes
Nasal cycle of rhythmic congestion and decongestion varies every 2.5 to 4 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about physiology of nose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sinuses are mainly ventilated during inspiratory phase of respiration
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
• The sinuses are ventilated during expiratory phase of respiration.
• The inspiratory and expiratory air currents pass through middle part of nasal cavity
• Nasal cilia beat 10-20 times per second and mucociliary clearance time is 10 -20 minutes.
• Nasal cycle of rhythmic congestion and decongestion varies every 2.5 to 4 hours

questions.text: 70 yr old patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma was operated as shown in the image. Identify the procedure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Total Maxillectomy
Sol:  
• Total maxillectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat advanced tumors of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, including maxillary sinus carcinoma. 
• It involves removing the entire maxilla (upper jaw bone) along with surrounding structures depending on tumor involvement.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal trauma following a road traffic accident. Lateral X-ray of the nasal bone shows a displaced nasal bone fracture.Which instrument is commonly used for reduction of nasal bone fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Walsham forceps
Sol:-                           
Explanation:
 Walsham forceps: Used for lateral nasal bone fracture reduction.
 Asch forceps: Specifically used for septal fracture reduction.
 Killian’s speculum: Used for nasal cavity examination, not fracture reduction.
 Septal elevator: Used for elevating mucoperichondrium during septal surgery.

questions.text: Choose the correct statements regarding the pathology shown in the slide: 1. Disease primarily affects the mucosa membranes of urethra and skin 2. The histopathology describes the presence of abundant, enormous, thick-walled sporangia. 3. The disease is most common in rural areas in the second and third decades of life 4. High relapse rate. 5. Dapsone is widely chosen to control the disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2,3,4 and 5
Reference: Read the text below
Sol:    

1.The histopathology describes the presence of abundant, enormous, thick-walled sporangia containing spores in a background of stratified squamous epithelium surrounded by neutrophils, lymphocytes and  plasma cells. 
2. The paranasal CT shows an enhancing soft tissue mass in the right naso-ethmoidal region  entirely occupying the space of the right maxillary sinus, and encroaching on the right frontal recess, left middle meatus, and sphenopalatine region.The view depicts erosion of the nasal septum, abutted by soft tissue lesions.

  Rhinosporidiosis primarily affects the mucosa membranes of the nasopharynx in 70–75% of cases (especially the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and nasal septum), conjunctiva and lacrimal sac (15%), and less commonly, other body parts (estimated 10%, including the urethra and skin).
  The disease is most common among the low socioeconomic cohorts living in rural areas in the second and third decades of life.
  At present, dapsone is widely chosen to control the disease.
  The high relapse rate of the disease warrants long-term follow-up and regular endoscopic surveillance.

questions.text: The organ of Corti is located in which of the following fluid compartment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Scala media
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• The organ of Corti lies within the scala media, which contains endolymph. The scala vestibuli and tympani both contain perilymph and no neural structures.

questions.text: A patient present with hearing loss.On examination rinnes negative on left side and positive on right side .Weber was lateralized to left side. Choose most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Left Conductive Deafness
Sol:-
• The most appropriate diagnosis for a patient presenting with a negative Rinne test on the left side, a positive Rinne test on the right side, and a Weber test lateralized to the left is unilateral conductive hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: Study the given image and comment on the stage in which it is seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Stageof pre suppuration
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
Stage of pre-suppuration. 
If tubal occlusion is prolonged, pyogenic organisms invade tympanic cavity causing hyperaemia of its lining. Inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear. Tympanic membrane becomes congested.
Symptoms. Th re is marked earache which my disturb sleep and is of throbbing n ature. Deafness and tinnitus are also present
Signs. 
• To begin with, there is congestion of pars tensa.
Leash of blood vessels appear along the handle of malleus and at the periphery of tympanic membrane imparting It a cart-wheel appearance. 
• Later, whole of tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red.
Tuning fork tests will again show conductive type of hearing loss.

questions.text: 7 year old child presented on hard of hearing, was suspected of having sensorineural deafness.Which of the following would not be the part of management:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Grommet insertion with adenoidectomy
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:

 SENSORINEURAL DEAFNESS
 
Hearing aids
 
Cochlear implant

Classroom accommodations


Grommet insertion with adenoidectomy is the treatment option for conductive deafness

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gradenigo’s syndrome
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
The given scenario is a typical presentation of Gradenigo’s Syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrositis (a complication of otitis media).
Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:
- Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy)
- Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
- Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.text: A patient present with ear discharge and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination shown below Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MRM
Sol:-
Let’s Dissect each option
a. MRM (Modified Radical Mastoidectomy)
  Indicated in chronic suppurative otitis media – cholesteatoma
  Otoscopy usually shows attic perforation or cholesteatoma debris

b. Myringoplasty
  Indicated in dry central perforation without infection
  Not performed in active discharge

c. Atticotomy
  Performed for limited attic cholesteatoma
  Used if disease is confined to attic only

d. Exploratory tympanotomy
  Done for sensorineural hearing loss or conductive loss with intact TM to explore ossicular pathology

questions.text: Patient with history of ear discharge and perforation presents with swelling in front of pinna as shown in the image. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Luc’s Abscess
Sol:  
• Luc’s Abscess
Definition: Subperiosteal abscess anterior to the pinna due to spread of infection from the mastoid through the tympanomastoid suture (foramen of Huschke).
Location: Preauricular / zygomatic root region
Etiology: Complication of CSOM

Other Options Explained:

• Zygomatic abscess:

Swelling above and lateral to the orbit/zygoma, not preauricular

• Bezold’s abscess:
Mastoid infection breaks through medial mastoid tip → Neck abscess in digastric triangle

• Citelli’s abscess:
Mastoid infection spreads to occipital / posterior neck area via mastoid emissary vein

questions.text: An elderly diabetic male presents with severe pain in the ear. On examination he is found to have granulation in external ear, conductive deafness and facial palsy. He was found to be having increased uptake of Tc99m.Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Malignant otitis externa 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• This is a case of malignant Otitis externa. 
• For early diagnosis Tc99 scan is used. Tc99 is taken up by the osteoclasts and osteoblasts and indicates the bony erosion during the malignant Otitis externa. 
• Malignancy of EAC usually follows long standings ear discharge which has not been mentioned in the above question. 
• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma with ET blockade presents with upper cervical lymphadenopathy with U/L serous otitis media.

choices.text: The sensorineural hearing loss are commonly associated with transverse fractures
Dysequilibrium may be caused by physical fatigue.
Facial paralysis is seen commonly in transverse fractures.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding “Temporal bone fractures” except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

About 20% are longitudinally placed. 
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
• It may do if the fracture has not transgressed the otic capsule. Commonly there is a conductive loss due to damage of middle ear structures. 
• In unilateral vestibular failure the subsequent compensation may breakdown if other sources of sensory information are excluded. e.g. failing eyesight, fatigue, illness and drugs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of increasing hearing loss for over 15 years. Her audiogram is shown as follows. She also undergoes computed tomography (CT) scanning of the temporal bones. The scans are shown as follows. Which is the next treatment option for hearing rehabilitation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hearing Aids
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
• The diagnosis is otosclerosis with cochlear involvement or fenestral and cochlear otosclerosis. The ‘double ring’ sign around the cochlea on CT is typical of this disease. Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to a similar CT appearance but is far less common in the temporal bone.
• Various drug treatment strategies have been proposed for stabilising hearing with inner-ear involvement. There are several studies (although relatively low grade) suggesting that uoride treatment may slow the progression of sensorineural hearing loss, although the dosage and treatment duration is very heterogenous in these studies. More recently, bisphosphonates, particularly third-generation bisphosphonates, such as zoledronate or risedronate, have been suggested to be useful in stabilising hearing as well.
• Hearing rehabilitation options always include standard hearing aids. In few cases, consideration should strongly be given to stapedotomy to close the air-bone gap followed by hearing aids. This would allow much better function with the hearing aids. The third option is cochlear implantation. But it should be considered if hearing is not satisfactory with hearing aids even after stapedotomy or stapedectomy.

questions.text: A man 50 years of age present with tinnitus, ear fullness and hearing loss in his right ear. Seven years later, he began to experience vertigo, headache, and progressive loss of balance. After 2 years, audiometry showed moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear that has not been investigated. On HPE slide Antoni A and Antoni B cells were seen. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vestibular schwannoma
Sol:-
Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas) and Other Cerebellopontine Angle Tumors
Acoustic Neuroma Histologic Types
1. Antoni Type A: histologically parallel nuclei, uniform spindle cells, compact cells
2. Antoni Type B: histologically less uniform, may have fatty or hyaline degeneration, less cellular

questions.text: Choose the correct statements regarding investigation shown in the given image 1. cVEMP tests inferior vestibular nerve 2. cVEMP is an inhibitory potential 3. oVEMP is an excitatory response. 4. oVEMP is primarily a utricle response 5. oVEMP tests inferior nerve response
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 1,2 and 3
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• We have to understand the difference between the cervical VEMP (cVEMP) and the ocular VEMP (oVEMP). 
• The cVEMP tests saccule and inferior nerve. It is recorded from the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM). It is an inhibitory potential and an ipsilateral response. When a muscle is flexed, there is a split second within that flex where it releases. That provides the waveform or the response from the sound.
• The oVEMP is primarily a utricle and superior nerve response.  A little part of this oVEMP response comes from the saccule. This is an excitatory response that we record from the extraocular muscles.

choices.text: Vestibular evoked Myogenic potential is helpful in its diagnosis.

questions.text: All of the following are true about superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome except

Sensorineural hearing loss

• Vestibular evoked Myogenic potential is helpful in its diagnosis.

Blood glucose levels have been well controlled preceding the hearing loss. Which of the following represents the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transtympanic dexamethasone
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• Of the choices offered, transtympanic steroid injection is the best choice. 
• A medrol dose pack may not provide sufficient dosing for body weight if the patient is insulin-dependent. Antiviral medications have not been shown to be effective in idio-
pathic sudden SNHL.
Carbogen (5

questions.text: Identify the hearing Aid shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

BTE
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Behind-the-ear (BTE) aids: Most parts are contained in a small plastic case that rests behind the ear; the case is connected to an earmold or an earpiece by a piece of clear tubing. This style is often chosen for young children because it can accommodate various earmold types, which need to be replaced as the child grows. Also, the BTE aids are easy to be cleaned and handled, and are relatively sturdy.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male professional football player suffered from acute-onset dizziness following a lower limb soft tissue treatment in prone lying. Symptoms included spinning vertigo lasting for 30's, headache, visual vertigo and disorientation. Clinical examination of balance and vestibular systems confirmed a left posterior canalithiasis benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) and excluded other central and peripheral causes of dizziness.Doctor initially performed a maneuver and the try to treat the patient with a maneuver, Identify the diagnostic maneuver:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dix-Hallpike maneuver
Ref:Read the text below.
Sol:-

questions.text: 15 year-old male, presents with left hearing loss since birth and left facial paralysis from the age of 3 years and 6 months, during one of the innumerous episodes of otorrhea and otalgia experienced during childhood. Physical examination showed left peripheral facial palsy Temporal bone computed tomography (CT scan) showed complete absence of inner ear cavities on the left. Patient was planned for auditory rehabilitation.The implant will be designed to stimulate the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cochlear nuclear complex.  
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
                                       AUDITORY BRAINSTEM IMPLANT (ABI)
• Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation. 
• The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel’s)
• This implant is designed to stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem directly. 
• Such an implant is needed when CN VIII has been severed in surgery of vestibular schwannoma.In these cases, cochlear implants are obviously of no use. 
• In unilateral acoustic neuroma, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side but in bilateral acoustic neuromas as in NF2, rehabilitation is required by ABI.
• Brainstem implant is similar to “Nucleus” multichannel cochlear implant except that the multielectrode array is attached to a Dacron mesh, which is placed on the brainstem.
• Receiver/stimulator has a removable magnet so that MRI can be safely performed in such cases if need arises.
ABIs help in communication, awareness and recognition of environmental sounds; however, they are not as efficient as multichannel cochlear implants.

questions.text: A patient of bell’s palsy shows no improvement with 3 weeks of steroid therapy.What should be the next steps in the management 1. Physiotherapy 2. IV steroids 3. Electroneuromyography 4. Facial nerve decompression if degeneration present. 5. Transtympanic dexamethasone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 3 and 4
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• Bell’s palsy is idiopathic sudden onset lower motor neuron facial palsy. 
• In lower motor neuron facial palsy, forehead muscles are also involved .(Supranuclear spares the forehead). 
• Herpes simplex is being postulated as an aetiology for Bell’s palsy.Steroids are the main stay of management. 
• A patient who reports within first three days should be given acyclovir as well. 
• Care of the eye is a very important part of management to prevent exposure keratopathy. 
• Chances of recovery in Bell’s palsy are 85% and above.
• If there is no recovery after 3 weeks of steroid therapy, electrophysiological nerve testing should be done ( Electroneuronography). 
• If there is significant facial nerve degeneration, patient should be taken for surgery (facial nerve decompression) should be done.

choices.text: The pathology is proximal to the stapedial branch of the VIIth nerve.
The pathology is distal to the stapedial branch of the VIIth nerve.
The patient has a left acoustic neuroma.
The facial paralysis is probably nonorganic in nature.

questions.text: Ramesh is a 34-year-old man with a sudden-onset, left-sided facial paralysis that has been diagnosed as Bell’s palsy. Acoustic reflexes --Present Lacrimation --Present Taste---Absent Which of the following statements accurately applies to this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The pathology is distal to the stapedial branch of the VIIth nerve.
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
• The acoustic reflex measurement helps to determine the site of lesion of facial nerve disorder as either distal or proximal to the stapedial branch of the VII th nerve.
• If the acoustic reflex is present at normal HTLs, the localization of pathology is likely distal to the stapedius branch of the nerve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pyriform fossa

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, a known case of chronic hypertension and diabetes mellitus, presents with severe epistaxis. Initial methods of controlling the epistaxis, including anterior and posterior nasal packing, have failed.What is the next best step in management, and which artery should be ligated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ligation of sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic approach
Sol:-
In refractory posterior epistaxis, after conservative measures fail:
 Endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (SPAL) is the standard next step.
 Sphenopalatine artery is the terminal branch of maxillary artery, which supplies the posterior nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with progressive nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On imaging, a vascular mass is seen occupying the nasopharynx and extending to the pterygopalatine fossa with pressure over the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
Sol:-
Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
• Age & Gender: Typically affects adolescent males (second decade). Symptoms: Recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction.
• Imaging Finding: Extension into pterygopalatine fossa may cause anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxilla – Holman-Miller sign.
• Nature: Benign but highly vascular tumor → biopsy is avoided due to risk of severe bleeding.

questions.text: Enlarged orange tonsils as shown in image is found in :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tangier disease
Sol:-
• In tangier disease there is a DEFECT IN EFFLUX OF CELLULAR CHOLESTEROL, leading to cholesterol accumulation in reticuloendothelial cells.
• ENLARGE ORANGE TONSILS are pathognomonic of tangier disease.

questions.text: 56 yr old patient from north east complaining of hearing loss and facial numbness. On otoscopic examination tympanic membrane appears to be dull.On tympanometry B type graph was seen.Neck examination reveals lymph node swelling in the posterior triangle on the right side. Choose the most appropriate management.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radiotherapy
Sol:     

TREATMENT OF CHOICE FOR NASOPHARYNGEAL CARCINOMA 
• Chemotherapy. Several factors are taken into account in deciding the chemotherapy regimen. Firstly, efficacy: the figures for event-free survival are similar for most small chemotherapy series but therapy usually involves fairly high-dose radiotherapy to the nasopharynx – 60 to 65 Gy. However, the most promising results with a recent update, are those obtained using the Mertens protocol NPC-91-GPOH (Society of Pediatric Oncology and Hematology).
• Radiotherapy. Although treatment with radiotherapy controls the primary tumor,it does not prevent the appearance of distant metastases Radiotherapy is given with megavoltage equipment after initial chemotherapy. A maximum dose of 45 Gy is given to the clinical target volume, which is a 1 cm margin around the MRI-detected primary site, and inferiorly down to the clavicles to include the lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 2 year old child while having dinner suddenly becomes aphonic and is brought to the casualty for the complaint of respiratory distress with history of eating custard apple. What should be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Heimlich maneuver
Sol:

questions.text: Which sign is being shown on the given X-Ray
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Double ring sign.
Ref:Read the text below
Sol

• Halo sign (double ring sign) in AP view of the x-ray are pathognomonic for button battery ingestion compared to a coin.

questions.text: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection is most commonly associated with which tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oropharyngeal carcinoma
Sol:  

• HPV, especially types 16 and 18, is strongly linked to oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, particularly tonsillar and base of tongue cancers.
• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is usually associated with EBV (Epstein–Barr virus).
• Laryngeal and oral cavity carcinomas are mainly linked to tobacco and alcohol rather than HPV.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male smoker presents with a hoarse breathy voice for 4 weeks. Initial endoscopic examination shows the following images.What is the next best investigation to perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 CT scan
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
• A computed tomography (CT) scan from base of skull to diaphragm in order not to miss any pathology along the course of the vagus and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN). 
• The course of the left RLN is much longer than the right RLN. 
• The right sided RLN leaves the vagus nerve at the root of the neck whereas the left RLN leaves the vagus nerve in the chest cavity and then loops around the arch of the aorta before traveling back up to the neck.
• Treatment should be determined based on the patient’s functional needs and demands.
• Treatment usually starts with voice therapy to educate patients on proper compensation techniques.
•  Surgical intervention may involve vocal fold injection, medialis ation thyroplasty or re-innervation surgery. 
• It was considered good practice to adopt a watch and wait policy in the rest 6 months in case spontaneous cord function returns, but there is reasonable evidence now in support of early temporary cord injection, which demonstrates better long-term voice outcomes.

questions.text: A two year old child presents with difficulty in breathing and an inspiratory stridor,following an episode of upper respiratory tract infection.X-ray taken is shown below.What’s your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Acute Laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis
Sol:     
• The Xray shows the Steeple sign seen in Acute Laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis (Croup) .It is 
• The most common organism responsible for croup is Parainfluenza virus type 1

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch. On examination vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the nerve may be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 External Laryngeal  Nerve
Sol:  
a. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses and elongates the vocal cords, allowing high-pitch phonation.
Injury to this nerve → loss of ability to raise pitch, bowed vocal cord, and voice fatigue in singers.
b. Recurrent laryngeal nerve affects most intrinsic laryngeal muscles and leads to hoarseness, not isolated pitch loss.
c. Internal laryngeal nerve is sensory above the vocal cords.
d. Glossopharyngeal nerve is unrelated to vocal cord movement.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Upper airway examination
Ref:Read the text below
Sol :  
The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions-
1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction
2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space
3. Uses a cuff to protect the airway from secretions
4. Allows suction of secretions in impaired cough reflex
5. Allows administration of anesthesia

choices.text: Vascular ring, bilateral VFP, vallecular cyst

questions.text: Which of the following would cause a characteristic “washing machine” type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tracheomalacia, tracheal stenosis, vascular ring
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
• Congenital tracheal stenosis with complete tracheal rings is often related to the presence of a pulmonary sling. 
• This sling is a result of the development of a left pulmonary artery coming off the right pulmonary artery, wrapping itself around the trachea at a fetal stage of development. 
• The failure of the development of trachealis or a C-shaped tracheal ring at birth leads to the condition, and if it involves a significant segment of the trachea, the neonate will go on to develop the washing-machine-type stridor characteristic of these cases.

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with throat pain, fever and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
Ref:Read the text below
Sol :  
• The tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis. 
• The referred pain may be secondary to lesions or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate or posterior one third of the tongue.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total laryngectomy
Sol:-
• Total laryngectomy indicated for T3 and T4 cases.
• Post-op, the airway and alimentary tract are permanently separated.
• The patient breathes through a permanent tracheal stoma — no air passes through nose/mouth.
